column4: Hello, I have a Gutsy install that is not pulling down an IP address from DHCP, but has all the drivers installed and I am posting this from a Gutsy laptop at the same time the desktop is running. So it's not a Linux issue. Please help!
No, I can't even execute a ping command.
To my Local net*
I.E. 192.168.0.1-254 I get nothing.
you can try running the dhclient command on the command line (Just "sudo dhclient eth#" where eth# is your network card [ussually eth0]) and see if you get any type of errors
When I run that command from terminal I get good results and it binds to 192.168.0.42, but still no internet access or ability to ping local IP's.
run ifconfig and make sure the ip / netmask and other settings look ok
Stupid question "What is bcast in Linux's ifconfig?"
broadcast, it should normally be 192.168.0.255 on a 255.255.255.0 netmask
Then everything looks fine IP of 192.168.0.42 bcast of 192.168.0.255 and standard netmask.
so pings to other local addresses that are local do not work?
It now pings to 192.168.0.1-254, but not to my net at the other end of a point to point T1 that has the local IP range of 192.168.1.1-254. It needs to ping to that to get out to the net.
I have my laptop running the same config and it is not having any problems so I doubt it's just Linux unfriendly hardware.
your laptop is also on the 192.168.0 network and can ping the 192.168.1?
check the output of route -n on your laptop and desktop and compare
Yes, just double checked.
and this is probably a stupid question, but the netmask and broadcast are the same on desktop and laptop?
My laptop was having similar problems earlier today, but it resolved itself mysteriously.
I will check.
They are the same.
honestly this goes beyond my understanding then :-( good luck with it
Don't worry I bashed my head with my laptop for 2 hours today for it to mysteriously start working tonight.
